channel.title: Textures look wierd?
channel.description:
So my textures look fine:
[IMG]http://i61.tinypic.com/jr2yqc.png[/img]
But in game it looks like:
[IMG]http://i59.tinypic.com/2wqwncg.png[/img]
Any ideas?
Im just trying to make a solid color

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Well that’s great to hear!

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Just downloaded GIMP, changed color index to 255 and boom! All the visual issues I’ve had in my game are gone!

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

If the problem is the bit depth (color depth), you have to save the image using a program such as Gimp, where you can specify this. But, go to the companion website of the book. There you can download textures with the correct bit depth (as part of various chapters). Try them out first. If they work, then the probable cause is the bit depth.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Okay, so how can I fix this haha

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Yes, but that’s because the ShadedTexture class contains a so called shade table. It uses a palette with shade values to apply to another Texture instance. So a ShadedTexture actually uses two Texture instances; namely itself and another Texture instance with the image to use.

Edit: I really meant the class ShadedSurfaceTexture uses the ShadedTexture and data from another Texture to create the texture being shown in the game. The ShadedTexture only contains the shade table.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

The book uses UShort for non shaded images.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I think the book uses 16 bits as bit depth (or color depth). It essentially means how many bits you use for one pixel. So the book uses DataBufferUShort, rather than DataBufferInt, which I use in my code.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_depth

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“object, post:16, topic:545801”]Okay, then did you save your image with the correct bit depth? I don’t remember the books bit depth, but I had to change it, in order to support the alpha channel and transparency.

The ShadedTexture class uses a palette (IndexColorModel) with a small limited number of possible shading values to save memory, just so you know. That’s why it uses BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED. It has 64 levels of shades.[/quote]
Sorry but what’s bit depth and how can I adjust it for a .png?

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Okay, then did you save your image with the correct bit depth? I don’t remember the books bit depth, but I had to change it, in order to support the alpha channel and transparency.

The ShadedTexture class uses a palette (IndexColorModel) with a small limited number of possible shading values to save memory, just so you know. That’s why it uses BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED. It has 64 levels of shades.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

object:

If you want it to be a solid color, why even bother with the ShadedTexture? It needs PointLights to calculate the shading. Or do you have PointLights?

I do have point lights and I’m just trying to do this solid color so it can look like a skybox… which is another thing i need to learn how to do.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

If you want it to be a solid color, why even bother with the ShadedTexture? It needs PointLights to calculate the shading. Or do you have PointLights?

item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“object, post:12, topic:545801”]Did you create the shade table? Or did you save the image with the correct bit depth?

I see you’re using parts of the code from either the book Developing Games in Java, or my code.

https://github.com/WavePropagation/JOGE/blob/master/src/main/org/macroing/joge/geometry/java2d/Java2DTextures.java[/quote]
Yeah its from the game book and making it a DataBufferInt has been a pain…

I see you’re using parts of the code from either the book Developing Games in Java, or my code.

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:9, topic:545801”] BufferedImage newImage = new BufferedImage(image.getWidth(), image.getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED); [/quote]
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/awt/image/BufferedImage.html#TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED

That doesn’t look like what you want to do there, I’m sure you could just use BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB as the image type.

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @sorecheeny sorecheeny
item.description:
@sorecheeny wrote:

It looks like an optical illusion

Read full topic

item.title: Textures look wierd?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

eyeownyew:

Are you using any libraries? You’ll probably just have to give us all relevant code. It seems you don’t have much anyway so if you gave someone a working copy they might be able to help figure out how to fix it.

Nope no other libs

if (type != BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED) { BufferedImage newImage = new BufferedImage(image.getWidth(), image.getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_BYTE_INDEXED); Graphics2D g = newImage.createGraphics(); g.drawImage(image, 0, 0, null); g.dispose(); image = newImage; } DataBuffer dest = image.getRaster().getDataBuffer(); return new ShadedTexture(((DataBufferByte)dest).getData(), countbits(width-1), countbits(height-1), (IndexColorModel)image.getColorModel());

Read full topic

[/quote]
